thread.title: Corruption Currents: Kremlin Critic Briefly Detained in Spain

author: Samuel Rubenfeld
title: Corruption Currents: Kremlin Critic Briefly Detained in Spain
text:
0 COMMENTS Investor and Kremlin critic Bill Browder visited the Dutch parliament on May 23. Photo: European Pressphoto Agency
A daily roundup of corruption news from across the Web. We also provide a daily roundup of important risk & compliance stories via our daily newsletter, The Morning Risk Report, which readers can sign up for here . Follow us on Twitter at @WSJRisk.
Bribery:
Four Egyptian officials were arrested on allegations they took bribes from commodities firms. The firms weren’t identified. The articles had no comments from the officials. (Reuters, Bloomberg, ET)
The chief executive of Air Asia was booked by Indian authorities for allegedly paying bribes to obtain flying licenses. The airline denies the allegations, and the CEO didn’t respond to requests for comment. Meanwhile, Indian firms have lost 4% of their turnover to bribery. (OPIndia, Quartz, Aviator, FT, AA)
Israeli prosecutors are set to recommend an indictment of the premier in a luxury-gifts case. He has denied wrongdoing. (Haaretz, TOI)
Peru is asking U.S. authorities to extradite a former president to face bribery charges linked to Odebrecht. The article contained no comment from the ex-president. (AP)
Switzerland dropped bribery charges against Michel Platini, the former chief of the Union of European Football Associations. (Menafm)
Malaysian authorities detained the Vietnamese captain of a fishing boat on attempted-bribery charges. The article didn’t contain a response from the skipper. (SD)
Cybercrime:
Russia hacked hundreds of thousands of routers, the FBI said, telling people to reboot the equipment. (Reuters, NYT)
Money Laundering:
Latvia is investigating whether its banks were used as conduits for Russian funds used to interfere in elections and politics elsewhere. The country needs a new anti-money laundering chief, a U.S. official said. (Reuters, LSM)
Nigerian authorities are looking into money-laundering allegations against a former president, who called the claims fabricated. A former governor was among those arraigned in a separate case. A former lawmaker debunked claims that another former president used bribes to pass a federal budget. (PT, Today, TD, Nation)
Mexico said it had detained the wife of a drug baron on charges she laundered his funds. The article didn’t contain a response from the woman. (Reuters)
U.S. lawmakers are targeting the bank accounts of sex workers. (HuffPost)
Zimbabwe is amending its anti-money-laundering laws. (NewsDay)
Malta’s premier said the European Commission recognizes the country’s efforts against money laundering. But did the Maltese authorities miss red flags in a major case? (ToM, MI, ToM)
Laundering money through foreign-exchange markets is becoming more difficult in Pakistan. Meanwhile, authorities began an investigation into the former premier; he denies wrongdonig. (Dawn, Nation)
The woman who ran one of Israel’s biggest brothels pleaded guilty to money-laundering charges. (Haaretz)
Tax evasion keeps Africa poor. (Guardian)
Indian authorities are challenging acquittals in a money-laundering case. They continue work in other cases . (AA UNI,, PTI, MM, IT, IANS, PTI)
Sanctions:
The investor Bill Browder, who is a critic of the Kremlin, was briefly detained by Spanish authorities on a Russian arrest warrant. Mr. Browder has lobbied multiple Western countries to impose sanctions on Moscow. (Bloomberg, AP, FT)
Sanctions on Venezuela will remain in place despite the release of a U.S. prisoner, Vice President Mike Pence said. (BBC, LAT, AP)
A tale of an American businessman, three blacklisted Iranians and an imprisonment . (Politico)
A Swiss bank is dropping its Iran business . Russia’s Lukoil put its Iran plans on hold. China will host Iran’s president at a meeting to help avoid disruption of joint projects amid the U.S. resumption of sanctions. The EU is pressuring central banks to help Iran. (SwissInfo, Reuters, Reuters, Reuters, Handelsblatt)
North Korea continues to raise funds despite sanctions. Japan said it detected Chinese ships breaching U.N. sanctions. (FT, Reuters)
Whistleblowers:
The Commonwealth Bank of Australia whistleblower’s case is set to settle . (SMH)
More Jamaicans are reporting corruption. (JG)
General Anti-Corruption:
Kenyan officials arrested dozens of people in an alleged theft of around $78 million from a government agency . (BBC, SMH, Star, Star, Bloomberg, Tuko)
Sri Lanka backed an investigation into cricket match-fixing. (BBC)
China is investigating the chairman of a food company on corruption allegations. (Reuters)
South Africa was ordered to unfreeze the assets of a powerful family under investigation for corruption and influence peddling. Separately, authorities are investigating a mayor. (TL, Reuters, FT, LM, CP)
President Donald Trump continued his attacks on the U.S. special counsel ‘s probe ; Moscow said the inquiry is pointless. The investigations are turning up the heat on Donald Trump Jr. Instagram is the best window into Trump-era corruption. (HuffPost, Yahoo, Hill, WP, Politico, Reuters, NBC, BI, ThinkProgress, FastCo)
Myanmar’s anti-graft fight is gaining steam . (VOA)
